FacilityName: City of Weslaco Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary    [A?68.155]

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: (a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; (c) The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario; (d) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; (e) The five-year accident history; (f) The emergency response program; and (g) Planned changes to improve safety.

This four section report meets the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency for Prevention Program 3 [40 CFR 68] and the Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration [29 CFR 1910.119]. 

The City of Weslaco, Hidalgo County, Texas, contracts the operation of the facility to CH2M HILL OMI; therefore, it must operate as a Prevention Program 3. This document includes Process Safety Management as required by OSHA. Filemon Olvera, a Project Manager for CH2M HILL OMI, is the responsible official at the facility. 

The City of Weslaco Water Treatment Plant is located at the southeast corner of the intersection of Mile 5 West & Mile 9 North, Weslaco, Hidalgo County, Texas (north 26.184579 latitude and west -097.990300 longitude). Six one-ton containers of chlorine are stored in the facility.  Two of them are connected to the system at one time.  The facility is staffed 24-hours a day and operators check the chlorination building daily. Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatus (SCBA) are stored in the office located approximately 50 feet north of the chlorination building.

RMP regulations for Program 3 processes require the performance of a consequence analysis for one worst-case release sce

nario, estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint. The worst-case release scenario selected involved the complete loss of the Chlorine to the air. The 4,000 pounds worst-case release quantity selected represents the greatest amount held by interconnected vessels. The RMP*Comp32 results indicate that the maximum distance needed for the concentration of chlorine to reach the toxic endpoint (0.0087 mg/L) as a result of a 10-minute release of 4,000 pounds of chlorine is 1.9 miles. The total potentially affected population with the entire area of the circle is estimated at 19,580 persons. 

One alternative scenario was selected for the offsite consequence analysis. The scenario selected involves the failure of the regulator connections.  This failure results in the release of the entire contents of the containers over a period of 15 minutes. This is equivalent to a release rate of 267 pounds of chlorine per minute. The RMP*Comp32 dispersion modeling results indicate that 0.3 miles is the maximum distance for the concentration of chlorine to reach the toxic endpoint (0.0087 mg/L) as a result of a 15 minute release of 267 pounds of chlorine per minute. The total potentially affected population within the entire area of the circle is estimated at 680. 

Population estimates are based on 2000 U.S. Census Bureau data from LandView®5 and MARPLOT. The Weslaco population has increased more than 30% in the past decade, so the potentially affected population should be higher than the numbers used in this report.  Most of the growth in Weslaco has occurred outside of the 1.9-mile radius, therefore, although the population has increased, it has not increased 30% within the area in question. 

A search of MARPLOT Satellite and Topographic maps did not identify any offsite impacts of environmental receptors within the endpoint. Environmental receptors include natural areas such as national or state parks, forests, or monuments officially designa

ted wildlife sanctuaries, preserves, refuges, and federal wilderness areas.

No accidental chlorine releases have occurred at this facility. 

The Weslaco Water Treatment Plant Accidental Release Prevention Policy involves an approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices in compliance with all applicable EPA Prevention Program 3 requirements and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements. 

Chemical-specific prevention steps include availability of Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatus (SCBA) that operators wear during the connection/disconnection of chlorine, and staff awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine. Weslaco Water Treatment Plant personnel employed the HAZOP technique to conduct a Process Hazard Analysis. They discussed each question and recorded their answers. After answering the questions, they discussed the adequacy of the existing safeguards and recommendations for additional safeguards. The staff finished the Process Hazard Analysis with an equipment inspection. All equipment was inspected during the Process Hazard Analysis. The Process Hazard Analysis will be updated at least once every five years.  

Weslaco Water Treatment Plant ensures that each employee presently operating the process, and each employee newly assigned to these processes have been trained or tested successfully in the operating procedures listed above that pertain to their duties. Annual refresher training provided to each employee operating the chlorination process ensures that the employee understands and adheres to the current operation procedures of the process.

The Weslaco Water Treatment Plant emergency procedure addresses potential emergencies that can reasonably be expected to occur at the facility. The emergency response procedures consider dangers within the plant that may affect employees as well as dangers outside of the plant that may affect the public or the environment. These procedures comply with EPA Risk Management

Plan and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements set forth in 40 CFR 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119.

The Weslaco Water Treatment Plant personnel are not first responders, although they are trained in response techniques and will notify other first responders in the event of an accidental chlorine release. An emergency response plan is kept on-site where all employees have access to it. Chemical Response and Remediation Contractors, Inc., is the first responder, as well as the Weslaco Fire Department.

The City of Weslaco Water Treatment Plant posts escape plans within the facility where any person entering can see them. Facility personnel receive training in the escape plans to leave the building and to leave the area once outside the building.
